predicted_rewrite: Tell me about the Bronze Age collapse.
predicted_response: The Bronze Age collapse is a transition in the ancient Near East, Anatolia, the Aegean region, North Africa, the Caucasus, the Balkans and the Eastern Mediterranean from the Late Bronze Age to the Early Iron Age, a transition which historians believe was violent, sudden, and culturally disruptive. The palace economy of the Aegean region and Anatolia that characterised the Late Bronze Age was replaced, after a hiatus, by the isolated village cultures of the Greek Dark Ages. In the first phase of this period, almost every city between Pylos and Gaza was violently destroyed, and often left unoccupied thereafter: examples include Hattusa, Mycenae, and Ugarit. According to Robert Drews: "Within a period of forty to fifty years at the end of the thirteenth and the beginning of the twelfth century almost every significant city in the eastern Mediterranean world was destroyed, many of them never to be occupied again." The gradual end of the Dark Age that ensued saw the rise of settled Neo-Hittite Aramaean kingdoms of the mid-10th century BC, the emergence of the Kingdom of Israel and the renewed emergence of the kingdoms of Phoenicia (by c. 800 BC), and the Neo-Assyrian Empire (911-605 BC).

The palace economy of the Aegean region and Anatolia that characterised the Late Bronze Age was replaced, after a hiatus, by the isolated village cultures of the Greek Dark Ages.

Despite appropriate treatment, about 10 to 20% of people develop joint pains, memory problems, and feel tired for at least six months.

predicted_rewrite: What is the Surrealism movement in art?

Its aim was to "resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality into an absolute reality, a super-reality," or surreality.

Surrealism was a cultural movement which developed in Paris in the 1920s and is best known for its visual artworks and writings. Artists painted unnerving, illogical scenes with photographic precision, created strange creatures from everyday objects and developed painting techniques that allowed the unconscious to express itself. Their aim was to resolve the previously contradictory conditions of dream and reality. Surrealism developed out of the Dada activities during World War I and the most important center of the movement was Paris. From the 1920s onward, the movement spread around the globe, eventually affecting the visual arts, literature, film and music of many countries and languages, as well as political thought and practice, philosophy, and social theory.

Surrealism was an art movement in the 1920s and 1930s, which encompassed painting, sculpture, photography and cinema. Surrealist artists sought to channel the unconscious in order to unlock the power of the imagination. The movement was founded in 1924 by André Breton and the writers and artists associated with him. Surrealism was both an artistic and literary movement, with writers like Breton, Paul Éluard, Louis Aragon, and Philippe Soupault, as well as artists like Max Ernst, Yves Tanguy, André Masson, Salvador Dalí, and Joan Miró, among its founders and most notable members.

Surrealism was a European art movement that pursued a particular type of expression, one that can be described as well beyond the real, as irrational, as imaginative. It was an art of the subconscious and the unconscious, of dreams and fantasy, of the irrational and the hallucinatory. Its origins were in early 20th-century Dadaism, but the movement itself emerged following World War I and lasted until well after World War II. It fizzled out in the 1950s, but its influence was felt for decades thereafter. Surrealist art can be seen as a search for a new reality, for a new way of seeing and interpreting the world.

The movement was founded in 1924 by André Breton, a French writer, poet, and critic, who also published the movement's principal manifesto, the Surrealist Manifesto, the following year. The Surrealist movement has been a fractious one since its inception. At the end of World War II and the beginning of the Cold War, André Breton and other members of the group began to worry about the political leanings of some of its members and allegations that surrealism was inherently fascist. The breakaway group, led by Breton, continued to be known as Surrealism, while the group Breton had expelled is today often referred to as the Philadelphia School or, sometimes, as Post-Surrealism.

On the first day of 1924, André Breton, Louis Aragon, Paul Éluard, Philippe Soupault, and René Crevel met at the Café Cyrano, in the Place Blanche, in Paris. They then proceeded to the offices of La Révolution surréaliste and composed the first Surrealist manifesto. That evening they installed themselves in Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre, a Romanesque church at the heart of the Latin Quarter, and there proclaimed the inauguration of the movement.

Pork ribs are cut from different parts of the hog. They are usually divided into three different types: baby back or loin ribs, spareribs or side ribs, and St. Louis or rib tips. Baby back ribs come from the top of the rib cage, between the spine and the spareribs. They are short, curved, and packed with meat. The tips are found at the end of the rack, closer to the belly. Because of their high fat and cartilage content, they are the least expensive and most flavorful. St. Louis ribs are spareribs trimmed of cartilage and sternum bone. This makes them more uniform in shape, which is why they are also called "center-cut ribs."

Baby back ribs are shorter and curved, and meatier than spare rib. Pork side ribs or spare ribs: These are taken from the belly side of the rib cage, below the section of back ribs and above the sternum (breast bone). Spare ribs are flatter than the back ribs and contain more bone than meat. The term "belly ribs" also is used, but this actually is a misnomer, as the ribs are taken from the side of the hog, not the belly. Lewis and Clark hired Charbonneau to guide them, and Sacagawea went along as an interpreter. Sacagawea was an important member of the expedition.
